'Ursula Kroeber Le Guin' (; born October 21, 1929) is an American author of
novels, children's books, and short stories, mainly in the genres of fantasy and
science fiction. She has also written poetry and essays. First published in the
1960s, her work has often depicted futuristic or imaginary alternative worlds in
politics, natural environment, gender, religion, sexuality and ethnography.

She was influenced by fantasy writers like J. R. R. Tolkien, by science fiction
writers like Philip K. Dick, by central figures of Western literature like Leo
Tolstoy, Virgil and the BrontÃ« sisters, and including feminist writers like
Virginia Woolf, by children's literature like [[Alice in Wonderland]], [[The
Wind in the Willows]], [[The Jungle Book]], by Norse mythology, and by books
from the Eastern tradition such as the [[Tao Te Ching]]. In turn, she influenced such Booker Prize winners and other
writers, as Salman Rushdie and David Mitchell â and notable futurism and fantasy
writers like Neil Gaiman and Iain Banks. She has won the Hugo
Award, Nebula Award, Locus Award, and World Fantasy Award, each more than
once.
